title: Carrie F. Butler Thwing;
snippet: I was in torture from the Trossachs to Callendar while five out of eleven passengers puffed clouds of vilest smoke into face, eyes and nostrils.

title: Carrie F. Butler Thwing;
snippet: Friday, July 24, we spent in the Scottish lakes, our course being Glasgow to Balloch by rail passing Dumbarton;  Balloch to Inversnaid by steamer on Loch Lomond, Inversnaid to Sconachlacher by coach, five miles, lunch there and then steamer on Loch Katrine to the Trossachs, through the Trossachs and by coach to Callendar, Callendar by rail to Edinburgh.

title: Carrie F. Butler Thwing;
snippet: Friday, July 24, we spent in the Scottish lakes, our course being Glasgow to Balloch by rail passing Dumbarton;  Balloch to Inversnaid by steamer on Loch Lomond, Inversnaid to Sconachlacher by coach, five miles, lunch there and then steamer on Loch Katrine to the Trossachs, through the Trossachs and by coach to Callendar, Callendar by rail to Edinburgh.

title: The works of the Right Rev. John Sage,
author: Sage, John
snippet: Soon after this period, he was requested by Anne Countessof Callendar, and grand-daughter of the famous Marquis ofMontrose, to become her domestic chaplain, and preceptor toher son, the young Earl.l The circumstances of our authorat this time were such as to cause him gladly to avail himselfof so eligible a situation, by which, while he was serving hisMaker and benefitting his fellow-creatures, he would be prevented from being any longer a burden to his valued friends.

title: The footpath and highway:
author: Moran, Benjamin
snippet: We stopped at the village of Callendar, where my German  friend parted company with us, and pursued his way to the Highlands, while we shortly after proceeded on to Stirling.

title: The footpath and highway:
author: Moran, Benjamin
snippet: We took stage in the afternoon for Callendar, and rode over every inch of ground traversed by Fitz James in the chase.

title: Glimpses of Europe;
author: Johnson, Jesse
snippet: Shortly after leaving Callendar it commenced to rain, and in a short time it became a perfect downpour, driv- ^■ ing in our faces and starting little brooks which came flashing down the steep hillsides along the road ; but as no one travels in Scotland without a waterproof garment,  we were prepared with the necessary wraps, and, cheered by the opening and nearer views of the great ^ mountains, we faced the pelting rain in cheerful and almost joyous mood.

title: Glimpses of Europe;
author: Johnson, Jesse
snippet: The stage ride is about ten miles, and we found ourselves in a party of five, riding on top of a stage running from Callendar to the Trossachs.

title: Glimpses of Europe;
author: Johnson, Jesse
snippet: We came by rail to Callendar ; from c» there we took stage to this place.

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: the captain of Stirling, who was created Lord Livingstone of Callendar, and Great Chamberlain of Scotland.

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: " The regent is to be Lord Livingstone of Callendar."

title: The captain of the guard.
author: Grant, James
snippet: The first was Sir Alexander Livingstone, of Callendar, Eegent of Scotland, and governor of the young king, James II., then in his eleventh year.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.

title: Scotland Picturesque and Traditional. A pilgrimage with staff and knapsack
author: Todd, George Eyre.
snippet: St. Catharine'sAisle, too, the family burying-place, recalls the Jacobite efforts of theLivingstones, Earls of Linlithgow and Callendar, attainted after therebellion of 1715.

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Lilhgow, Callendar,Newburgh, Sinclair, Sir James laickhart of Lee, and Blackhall ; aud the report was.

title: Journal of a Residence in Scotland, and Tour through England, France, Germany, Switzerland and Italy. With a memoir of the author and extracts from his religious papers. ... Compiled by I. MacLellan, Jr
author: Maclellan, Henry B.
snippet: I left Stirling in the afternoon and rode as far as Callendar ; stopped there during the night; and in themorning, though in a violent rain, started off for the opening of the Trosachs.
